newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil may cut car tariff under quota system - paper.
newsitem.headline: Brazil may cut car tariff under quota system - paper.

text.p: Brazil may cut to as low as 31.5 percent from 35 percent its import tariffs on cars that enter the country under a quota system settled last year with Japan, South Korea and the European Union, a newspaper said.

"We are considering the reduction of the import tariff under the quota system," Jose Alfredo Graca Lima, head of the Foreign Ministry's Economic Deparment, was quoted as saying by Gazeta Mercantil financial newspaper.

Gazeta said Graca Lima made those comments after the first round of informal negotiations with Japanese officials in London. Earlier this week Graca Lima met with officials from the European Union to discuss Brazil's automotive regime as the quota system expires on August 20.
Brazil introduced the tariff system last year amid concern over its widening trade deficit and in a bid to stimulate foreign investment.
In a concession, Brazil created a quota system under which carmakers from the EU, Japan and South Korea were allowed to export a total of 50,000 cars a year to Brazil at the 35 percent tariff rate.
Graca Lima indicated the possibility of extending the quota system to further two years or even until December 1999, the paper said.

Lower car import tariffs would be the Brazilian response to growing pressure from the European Union. Newspapers have reported that the EU appears set to ask the World Trade Organization (WTO) to create a panel to look into Brazil's automotive regime despite a Brazilian offer to raise the EU's car import quota to 12,000 cars a year from 10,000 cars.
Graca Lima also said the government is unlikely to raise the total quota of 50,000 cars a year, Gazeta added.
